Accelerating the Sustainable Control and Elimination of Neglected Tropical Diseases (ASCEND - Lot 2) is a high profile, DFID-funded, multi-partner programme, which will make a significant contribution to the control and eliminatuion of the 5 PC NTDs, health systems strengthening, and cross-sector collaboration (particularly WASH and education) across 13 countries in Western and Central Africa. This project code is for central fees and expenses regarding Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine.
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Accelerating the Sustainable Control and Elimination of Neglected Tropical Diseases (ASCEND - Lot 2) is a high profile, DFID-funded, multi-partner programme, which will make a significant contribution to the control and eliminatuion of the 5 PC NTDs, health systems strengthening, and cross-sector collaboration (particularly WASH and education) across 13 countries in Western and Central Africa. This project code is for central fees and expenses regarding SCI.
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

In partnership with the UK government, Street Child is launching an ambitious programme to support 3,000 Musahar girls in some of the most remote regions of Nepal to access education and employment and therefore end the cycle of debt bondage. · We will support vulnerable girls to learn basic literacy and numeracy through an accelerated learning programme. · We will provide livelihoods support in the form of training and business grants so young Musahar women are financially independent. · We will organise weekly workshops where women and girls can access counselling and support, and learn important life skills - from understanding their rights, to basic hygiene practices.
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Short general project overview:Water scarcity is becoming an increasingly important issue worldwide due to increasing drought and a growing population. In metropolitan deltas, the possibilities for infrastructure expansion of water networks are limited, so that these drinking water systems reach their limits. This creates a discrepancy between the supply and demand of water and therefore an unsustainable water management. Grendel Games and Vitens have developed a serious game where the consumer is activated to reduce or shift water consumption. This reduces water demand and spreads better over the day, which can delay investment in infrastructure and may be needed to a lesser extent. The beneficiary is Thames Water, the drinking water company of the South East of England and the Thames River catchment area. This company is responsible for producing approximately 2 billion litres of clean drinking water per day, serving 5 million households and more than 10 million inhabitants. Due to local conditions, expansion and maintenance of the physical water network are undesirable and will hardly contribute to a reduction in water demand. Reducing water demand in this area is important because the metropolis continues to grow in population numbers and the water company is not allowed to extract additional groundwater to absorb this distortion. The use of behavioural changes through a serious game has a proven positive and lasting influence.The pilot project is intended to extend three successful tests in Leeuwarden, with these tests a 7% demand reduction and 2 to 3% peak levelling was achieved. With this pilot project, Grendel Games and Vitens want to demonstrate and further develop their innovative knowledge and expertise for water safety and water security in the metropolitan delta London. The game is largely played by children, who then urge their parents to realize water savings in the household. Based on information about water problems, the children solve puzzles and when they reduce or distribute their water consumption, more levels become available. They play in competition with the school, neighbourhood or district and are encouraged by means of prizes to achieve as many water savings as possible.Among the expected results is that the game will be played by at least 10,000 players, resulting in a consumption reduction and peak leveling of approximately 5 percentage points. In addition, the game should be perceived as useful and pleasant by the users. A successful pilot project translates into excellent opportunities to scale up the game in other regions within and outside the UK and in other areas of application.Initial activities and results of the project:With this pilot project, Grendel Games and Vitens want to demonstrate their innovative knowledge and expertise for water safety and water security on a limited but representative scale at Thames Water.   By demonstrating this knowledge and skills, one can scale up and sell the approach in follow-up to a successful project to a larger group of users, apply it in other regions and possibly also apply it in other settings such as influencing awareness and behaviour about energy use.  The approach of Grendel Games and Vitens brings about behavioural changes among users, by incorporating appropriate incentives into a serious game and/or app, young and old players are encouraged to reduce water consumption and in some cases specifically level peak consumption.  The goals of the project are:•	Increase user awareness of water use and water waste.•	Achieve representative ethnic diversity and geographical distribution among users.•	Customize or further develop the game so that it can be played independently and thus demonstrated independently.•	Customize or further develop so that the game becomes interesting for the widest possible age audience.•	Demonstrate demand-side total solution that reduces peak water consumption and water waste.•	Amassing qualitative and quantitative results that are representative of the City of London and can support its effectiveness in other regions.•	Tighten business models and market implementation plans based on project results, with the aim of achieving rapid scaling and associated (international) rollout. Our country has an international reputation for our knowledge and innovations in the field of water technology. This project will further confirm this reputation and ensure that both Grendel Games and Vitens can further achieve their international ambitions as specialists in the field of integral, serious game-based, demand-side driven total solutions for increasing water awareness and reducing peak load.  The Netherlands is at the forefront of the integrated approach, the preventive and participatory approach. The approach that Grendel Games and Vitens have developed fits in seamlessly with this and proves this once again: By bringing about behavioural changes on the demand side, through a participatory approach and from an integrated approach in which chain partners such as water suppliers, smart water meter suppliers, game developers and possibly knowledge institutions try to achieve an optimal effect together. The approach promotes prevention in relation to repair, thereby limiting the effects of water shortages. This is one of the benefits of betting on consumption reduction and peak levelling.What makes the technology, product, method or approach used innovative:The Water Battle is a game that focuses on lowering the final water demand by combining education with behavioral changes and by intervening on the demand-side. This is achieved by a game in which parents and children carry out assignments with tips and advice on water saving and the levels are concluded with a quiz on water, water problems and water scarcity. The game is linked to the (smart) water meter of the household with which water consumption is monitored. When a consumption reduction or peak leveling in water use is visible, more options become available in the game so that the user remains engaged with the game and the savings to be realized.A pilot was carried out in Leeuwarden. This has led to a water saving of 7% during the 'battle'. Whether this will have a lasting effect is not yet clear. Water Battle focuses on the demand side of water consumption and not on the distribution of water. Thames Water's working area is 25% water loss due to outdated poor infrastructure. This supply side of water consumption is not taken into account in this project proposal. Reducing water needs is a spearhead policy in the UK and relevant to water conservation. Serious gaming in the field of water saving on a large scale is new in the Netherlands and abroad. Behavioural influence in the field of water consumption by serious gaming is an innovative approach. Innovation and NL innovation is very good.
Water sector policy and administrative management
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Short general project overview:This application is for a pilot project for the feasibility study of innovative monitoring techniques (developed on the Sand Motor) and management (by means of a Digital Twin, near-time integration of a 3D model with simulation and monitoring data) of sandy coasts with a critical role in coastal safety, to be carried out on the Bacton Sand Engine in England which will be installed in the summer of 2019.Beach erosion threatens critical infrastructure, homes and the recreational value of beaches, and can lead to flood risk. This is the case in Bacton, but also elsewhere in England, and worldwide. In the past, hard coastal defenses were often used, but it is now clear that a soft solution (through beach replenishment) is more sustainable and economically advantageous in many locations. An additional advantage (certainly in England) is its adaptive nature: a sand motor-like solution "buys time" so that society can adapt to the inevitable erosion.Adaptive beach management is essential in that context. Beach Management Plans are used for this. This contains the management goals (safety but also recreation, nature, shared use); this is linked to 'triggers' for intervention, supported by a monitoring program and associated analysis to support intervention decisions.North Norfolk District Council (NNDC) is working in partnership with the Bacton Terminal Companies (BTC, including Shell and Perenco) towards the implementation of the Bacton Sand Engine, scheduled for March - October 2019. This is the first outdoor application of the sand engine concept The Netherlands. They have developed a management plan with a basic package of monitoring techniques and associated analysis. They also like to offer room for more innovative methods, and will consider adopting them if they prove successful (better decisions and / or lower costs).This application concerns the implementation of a 'plus package' for both monitoring (by application of techniques developed and applied to the NL Sand Motor) and for analysis and information management (through the development of a Digital Twin of the Sand Engine that translates monitoring data 'near real-time' into a 3D model, and on that basis runs a simulation model that predicts future developments, in support of management and investment decisions.What makes the technology, product, method or approach used innovative:The activities concern:• Actual implementation of advanced monitoring and processing of the results, in six cycles over the subsidy duration of two years;• Development and implementation of a Digital Twin of the Sand Engine;• Support for the end user in the application of the Digital Twin;The intended results are twofold:• For the Bacton project: better information to support decision making (about how much time there is to replenish again). This means there is less chance that people will wait too long (risk of major damage and casualties) or invest too early (unnecessarily high costs). In addition, operational decisions, regarding recreation, fishing, nature, and communication towards the public and stakeholders;• For the techniques: evaluation of the applicability and added value of the monitoring techniques and the Digital Twin concept for coastal management.
Water sector policy and administrative management
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

The overall objective of this project is to promote more evidence-based policy making and support the mainstreaming of migration into the policy-making process. Through this project, IOM facilitates the transfer of the remaining 148 of the 236 asylum-seeking unaccompanied and separated children that the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (UK) has accepted until 2020. IOM supports the resettlement of the 148 UASC from France, Greece and Italy to the UK through case management, pre-departure health assessments, pre-departure orientation and movement management activities, as well as information sessions for local UK authorities, in coordination with the French, Greek and Italian authorities.
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
The Facilitated Return Scheme (FRS) is a scheme run by the Home Office to provide support to non-EEA (European Economic Area) Foreign National Offenders who voluntarily depart the UK.
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Performance Evaluation of the AgriTech Catalyst International Development Window: The Service Provider (SP) will conduct a performance evaluation (“the evaluation”) of the AgriTech Catalyst International Development Window between 2019 and 2022. The evaluation will be commissioned through DFID’s Global Evaluation Framework Agreement (GEFA). This evaluation will complement an ongoing process evaluation of a number of Catalyst Programmes and an interim impact evaluation of the UK component of the AgriTech Catalyst, commissioned by Innovate UK (IUK) and the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) respectively. These studies have purposefully not select international development applicants and grantees for primary data collection. More detail is provided under the Constraints and Dependencies section of this TOR. The specific focus of the evaluation is to provide a rigorous and independent assessment of the effectiveness of the funding mechanism in stimulating agricultural innovation in and for developing countries.
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

The purpose of this evaluation is to better understand the development outcomes and impacts associated with CDC’s investments in the financial sector. Its key components will include:

A rapid review of CDC’s portfolio in the financial institutions sector using descriptive analysis to help highlight the outputs, outcomes and impacts intended and produced by CDC investments in the financial sector. This should provide a deeper understanding of CDC’s and its investees’ goals and work in this sector at each step along the impact pathway. It will help to identify what is understood about the outcomes and impacts of investments, where key questions and knowledge gaps remain, and where there are potential opportunities for further evaluation of these investments.
A targeted review and mapping of the evidence base on the impacts of financial institutions underpinning the work of CDC and its investees. Linked with the portfolio review described above, mapping CDC’s portfolio against the evidence base will help to draw out key lessons relevant to CDC and its investees, and provide insights into potential opportunities to increase impact.
A series of four to seven in‐depth studies addressing targeted research and evaluation questions relevant to CDC and/or its investees in the FI sector, including primary data collection. The finalisation of evaluation questions and study designs will follow on from the first two steps outlined above.
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

DFID’s Forest Governance, Markets and Climate (FGMC) programme is a 10-year (2011-2021), £250 million programme aimed at tackling forest governance failures in developing timber-producing countries and the consequent market failures that result in illegal exploitation of forest land and resources and the associated trade in timber and other forest risk commodities. As FGMC approaches the end of its current phase, there is a need to take stock, at programme level, of progress and the prognosis for further achievements. To meet this need, FGMC has commissioned a ‘Policy Evaluation and Learning Team’ (PELT) to carry out research, reviews and analysis, jointly with PMST and DFID, to address the overarching question of: ‘how, why, and under what conditions do forest-related governance and markets change, to what effect and to whose benefit?'
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

"IPE Global provides a monitoring and adaptive learning function to
the I-ACT programme. The core tasks are 
1. To monitor and systematically report programme outputs and (where possible)
outcomes;
2. To gather available evidence to support programme reporting (including Annual
Reviews), and lessons from partner learning day report (learning day to be
contracted separately);
3. To inform on-going operational decisions about programme delivery; and,
4. To identify synergies and innovative approaches to anti-corruption and transparency
between I-ACT and two other DFID centrally managed programmes (CMP)."
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

Agulhas Applied Knowledge is the Lead in the Service Provider Consortium to UK Independent Commission on Aid Impact (ICAI). ICAI’s formal remit is to provide independent evaluation and scrutiny of the impact and value for money of all UK Government ODA. This involves: (1) carrying out a small number of well-prioritised, well-evidenced, credible, thematic reviews on strategic issues faced by the UK Government’s aid spending, (2) informing and supporting Parliament in its role of holding the UK Government to account, and (3) ensuring our work is made available to the public.
Independent Commission for Aid Impact Gwydyr House Whitehall London SW1A 2NP
